This is a good series. Very happy with it. I like how it comes through on Amazon as well. Pleased.

Great acting, strong character development, intriguing and suspenseful.  The events that occur are not unrealistic and you never know what's going to happen next. I have always enjoyed viewing the Good Wife and I am very, extremely happy to able to get it on my Kindle.  With my busy schedule sometimes I have missed some episodes, Now I can watch them all with no commercials.  Absolutely great.  Anyone who has not watched the Good Wife should-very entertaining and no violence..
One of my favorite drama tv shows!  Now my friend is hooked so I'm watching the shows again on Amazon, and no commercials.

It is my favorite show on tv.  The writing is superb, the  acting, equally so.  Why this show has not received more awards is confusing to me.  Homeland is good, but not as consistently good as The Good Wife, which is very often brilliant.. Homeland is controversial, more nudity, so I guess that is awards are about.  Julianna is far superior to Clair Danes, in my opinion, it is so easy to play crazy!  To play normal is a challenge.

The cast does an excellent job, sometimes, I love them, then I'm mad at them, sometimes I loathe them, then somehow I love them again.  They never cease to amaze me with their storylines, and how they interweave characters from previous seasons.  Love it.
I love being able to re-watch "The Good Wife".  An excellent vehicle for Juliana Margulies and other good actors.  Thank you.

Love the feminist subplots! Also love the risks the writers take at showing people as real, vulnerable and even not so nice from time to time. The the sexual tension between Kalinda and everyone continues to be steamy. And kudos for maintaining the Will and Alicia tension and angst! So great to see such strong female characters! I want to grow up to be Diane Lockhart, lol!
Series includes something for everyone, always a case to solve, real life characters, various personalities and their lives and loves, plus family conflicts and resolutions.
Great show, would definitely recommend.  Season three was great.  The quality of the Amazon instant video was very good.  Would purchase a show on Amazon again.
I have been hooked since the first episode. Jackie continues to meddle and shake things up a bit. While Felicia handles her and her feelings with great dignity. Lots of new twists to keep you hooked.

I really like The Good Wife. I caught up on both Season 2 and Season 3 in a short time thanks to the free episodes on Amazon with the Prime membership. The characters in the series never disappoint. Now I am ready to jump into Season 4!

very clever writing.  great way to view the human experience.  moving, challenging - probably would be termed equivelent to a 'chick flick' by outward appearances, but much deeper significance and definitely a product of and for our times.  nps  ps / and having the first 4 seasons offered by amazon prime is truly amazoning!
The story evolves around and lady lawyer.  There is always a new problem that has to be handled by the main character.

I never knew what I was missing.  Well written and the characters are multi-layered and interesting.  I highly recommend it.
I watched all the original showings of The Good Wife and I enjoyed them as much the second time around.
like the caharacters and the way they are developed. a fun show to watch.  there are definitely winners and losers

Love the good wife. Can't wait til season 4 is available to watch for free. It's a great show but I'm not going to pay extra to watch.
This story shows a very strong, smart, ethical woman, mother, and lawyer trying to deal with betrayal and dishonesty and to always do what is best for her children and her clients.

To me, this series is about how to succeed in the business/political world, what makes a good leader, and how intellect, people skills and strategy are everything.  Yet another great season with a talented ensemble cast.

This review is for the condition of this "new" product.
While watching the second disk in this box, one of the shows froze, it wouldn't "skip" ahead, go back, stop, nothing. When we removed the disk from the player we discovered it was badly scratched. This was sold to us as new. However it was used and repackaged as new.
I will not buy from this seller again. To pay for a new product, and receive a repackaged used one is fraud.

Soooo good. I love this show & you will too.

Awesome!!! Can't wait to watch next season. Highly recommend it!!!! Love the progression from season to season. Alicia has matured as a lawyer

I had heard about this series but never got around to watching it. Thankfully Amazon Prime had it avaiable. I watched all the seasons available over a two week time period. This is a well-written show with well-developed characters and enough plot twists and turns to keep it fresh.

Holy Cow. Started watching the TV show on a whim. I borrowed the first two season dvds. And I couldn't stop. At first when it was advertised on national TV it did seemed like another law drama. Enjoy hours that you will lose from your life.

This show is one of the best lawyer shows I have ever seen. There is a little bit of everything for everyone here. The back plots and character renewals make this a pleasure to watch.

Hadn't had a chance to see this series when first aired, so I started watching it on Amazon from season 1 and couldn't get enough.  I think it's one of the best shows on TV with great acting and writing!

Best soap opera ever. Excellent writing, amazing casting, the actors are all very good, and the question foremost in my mind? What will Christine Baranaski be wearing in the next episode? That woman can dress! Alicia? not so much, but then she's not at the top of the food chain either. I like the women in the series, how they interact in the workplace. Personally, I've never seen women interact like men, but I'm all for it.  If Julianna Marguiles is the new Mary Tyler Moore, we have much to be thankful for. How does she do it?

I cut the cable, got rid of my TV about 14 years ago because I was so frustrated with the lack of quality entertainment: seemed to me the better the picture got, the worse the content was. While watching The Good Wife has made me run out to buy a flat screen TV, I'm impressed. Half a dozen shows like this one and maybe I will. Although, I have to say, it's great fun watching them back-to-back on Amazon.

Very believable actors/actresses.  I worked as a paralegal and law office administrator for 20 years.  I know that cases don't settle nearly as quickly as portrayed in this show, people don't hunt you down at private affairs to review evidence, and everybody isn't brilliant.  Even still, the cast does a phenomenal job with the script they've been given.  It astounds me how many of the women on this show wear 5 inch heels on a daily basis.  Their poor feet.  When I worked in the city we kept our nice heels under our desk for meetings, and changed into more comfortable shoes for simply walking around the office.

I enjoyed the beginning season of the show, but eventually the story line became redundant and a lot less interesting.  Finally, it looked like the writers seemed to realize the show wasn't developing the characters and the story wasn't "going anywhere", and it has improved greatly.  I have enjoyed the addition of Michael Fox.  His "difficult" and passive aggressive character has added to the story quite well.  I hope you will continue the series and working on the story line.

While there are parts of this program that I like, there are others that I would prefer not to see.  I don't think that trying to impose social views should be part of entertainment.  Some of the actors/actresses on the program are good and you either like them or dislike them.  I am learning a great deal about lawyers and Chicago.  It is certainly not a positive experience.  I really don't know if the program was designed to give viewers this negative view.  It's a good thing that older programs, such as Perry Mason or Murder She Wrote are still available for viewing.  You can watch about 50 minutes of these programs and actually enjoy them.  As for lawyers and "the Chicago way", I've learned a lot about how lawyers operate and the real wheeling and dealing of Chicago politics.  I always knew politics was a dirty business but never realized just how dirty.  I have now changed my opinion of what may be the lowest professions.  The mainstream media is now at the bottom, followed by politicians, then lawyers, and used car salesmen.  Used car salesmen is no longer at the bottom, in my opinion (as one of the judges on The Good Wife requires lawyers to say).
The casting is spot on and the acting is pretty good. Some of the episodic plot lines are a little goofy. But, the continuing story lines are well done.

The British former consultant to ..... Has been written poorly this time, I thought. First, how did he get to have such a large part in the law firm, so large he is contemplating a take-over? Very little he does is realistic; especially sex. There is no chemistry between him and the very unattractive woman who hovers about him, and professes her lust. Then he reciprocates, but it is totally unbelievable, and his going to bed with her seems just icky. Most of what this actor, who is a very good actor, does in this season seems weakly written and brings the show down.

The writers, in the comments, seem in love with their guest women; they laugh. I found them, the ex-wife of the Brit (Parker Posey? I should have refamiliarized myself with everyone's name since I have anomia) and the comedian Sedaris seem to have been inserted in a kind of blinders-on way, the way you might try to palm off stoned, hilarious 'creativity' even after the high wears off. I felt used, that someone's laziness wasted my time during all those too-long bits.

The actor who plays Kalinda, like all the actors, is very good. But her fluctuating British posh-not-posh accent is distracting. Sometimes I think some Brits have a very low opinion of Americans' view of British accents -- that they're all the same. But we've seen enough regional British movies that we can almost place some characters' accents within Britain and between classes. Kalinda's fluctuating one is distracting in itself but especially when she effects a more upper-class accent. Then, all I can think of is, 'she's doing that again'. It's perplexing, why this goes on.

I am delighted to report that Season 3 of my favorite network-TV drama is as consistently top notch across every episode as Season 1 and Season 2. As Season 3 opens, Alicia Florrick (Julianna Margulies) has emerged with greatly increased confidence in herself, both as a woman and as an attorney at Lockhart/Gardner, after the intense personal and professional struggles she endured during Season 2. She has left her husband Peter Florrick (Chris Noth) after finding out he had a one-night stand years ago with Kalinda Sharma (Archie Panjaba), the firm's mysterious private investigator. In spite of the fact that Kalinda did not know Alicia then, this explosive revelation makes it impossible for Alicia to be anywhere near Kalinda without feeling an overwhelming urge to scream at her friend or burst into tears--which is a real problem since they have to work together on cases at Lockhart/Gardner. Kalinda, who normally is a really tough nut, is shown at the end of Season 2 visibly heartbroken over losing her friendship with Alicia, which was clearly one of the closest relationships she'd ever had. On the heels of what Alicia sees as a double betrayal, she has kicked Peter out of their apartment and dumped him and his possessions into an apartment she obtained for him without his prior knowledge. As apparent retaliation, Peter, who has just been re-elected to his old office as State's Attorney, strictly because of Alicia's high-profile loyalty and support during his campaign, has hired Cary Agos (Matt Czuchry) to be his second-in-command. Cary has been Alicia's enemy since Season 1 when she beat him out for an associate position at Lockhart/Gardner. Alicia has begun talks with Lockhart/Gardner's barracuda divorce attorney, David Lee (the immensely talented Zach Grenier), and launched a torrid affair with Will Gardner (Josh Charles). For multiple reasons, Alicia and Will opt to keep their affair top secret: he is her boss, she is still legally married to Peter, and she doesn't want her kids to know about the affair. This show does a fantastic job this entire season, as it did the previous two seasons, delivering interesting cases for Lockhart/Gardner to represent. The series's excellent writers (led by award-winning, writer/producer, husband-and-wife team, Michelle and Robert King) keep these cases enthralling to viewers by offering spicy--and sometimes humorous--conflicts for the lawyers, such as client chicanery to be worked around, in-house rivalries threatening to torpedo the success of a given case, or mysteries for the ruthlessly capable Kalinda to solve in order to prove a client's innocence or win a case. In addition, whatever the overarching legal plot, it always deftly intertwines with several personal-relationship subplots every week. All of the main characters are linked to each other and numerous other subcharacters in an ever expanding web of secrets, lies and conniving. This could easily become confusing rather than pleasantly intriguing in less skillful hands than those of the show's writing team, but they never drop any plot threads, and never allow the show to slide into outright soapiness, a failing that seems to afflict the vast majority of nighttime drama. The acting continues to be terrific. I concur 100% with the Emmy wins of Julianna Margulies for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series, Archie Panjabi for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series, and the nominations of Josh Charles as Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series, and Christine Baranski, as Diane Lockhart, for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series. Though Matt Czuchry has not yet been nominated for an Emmy for this show, he contributes greatly to its success by his capable handling of his recurring role as ambitious attorney, Cary Agos. I quite enjoyed the growth arc of his relationship with Alicia this season. Czuchry's outstanding ability to portray Cary's intense emotions through subtle facial expressions--in keeping with the poker face that men in general employ, and lawyers especially are forced to cultivate--never fails to entertain. Mary Beth Peil as Jackie Florrick continues her excellent work as the ambitious mother of Alicia's husband, Peter, and Peter also gets a lot of stage time this season as he contemplates a run for the governor's office. This goal is made all the more fascinating because it is impossible to achieve without the cooperation of both Alicia and cagey political operative, Eli Gold. Eli is one of my favorites on a show overflowing with talented actors playing plum parts. Alan Cumming's portrayal of Eli is filled with delightful contradiction. Just when Eli's ruthlessness is about to push him over the edge into the territory of unsympathetic, irredeemable jerk, out peeks a soft-heartedness that is often quite funny to behold. After Season 1, Cumming received an Emmy nomination as Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series. Apparently because his work was so exceptional that year, he was promoted to a recurring role, and for Season 2, he received an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor. I could go on and on about the caliber of the many actors with recurring guest roles, but two in particular deserve special attention: Michael J. Fox received his 12th Emmy nomination for his portrayal of attorney Louis Canning, who cynically attempts to gin up sympathy from judges and juries for his Parkinson-type symptoms in order to win his cases. Martha Plimpton (Emmy winner as Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series for Raising Hope) plays cutthroat attorney Patti Nyholm who, like Louis Canning, uses a physical health condition--in her case pregnancy and later the baby that resulted from that pregnancy--to deceive and manipulate her opponents. If you haven't been watching this show every week, or even if you have, this DVD is a worthwhile investment in some of the best TV drama of this season or any other.

Cool! I get to live out the dream of being the first to review a popular product AND give a rave to the third season of one of my favorite shows on TV. I have to say: I have given a pass to nearly every network series of the past ten years, preferring the more complex and adult dramas and comedies found on cable-TV. But THE GOOD WIFE fulfills all of my requirements for great entertainment: gripping plotlines, complex characters and brilliant acting, writing and directing. Julianna Margulies anchors the show beautifully as Alicia Florrick, and Season 3 gives her great new material to play, particularly at the start of the season with her boss, Will Gardner (Josh Charles). How their affair plays out - and draws in her ex-husband Peter (Chris Noth) and her OTHER boss, Diane Lockhart (the always amazing Christine Baranski) makes for great drama that never descends to soapiness. Alan Cumming expands his role as Eli Gold, now practicing law in Alicia's office even as he juggles his career as a political consultant, and he provides many of the comic highlights throughout the season. Matt Czuchry deepens his portrayal of Cary Agos, having switched sides from defense to the D.A.'s office. And of course, there's my (and probably most other viewers') favorite character, Kalinda Sharma (Archie Punjabi) whose friendship with Alicia went up in smoke at the end of Season Two. The fallout of this event, as well as the other troubles she encounters, make Kalinda appear more vulnerable than ever before. By season's end, several intriguing questions about her character are answered, even as new mysteries surrounding her past begin. Chris Noth and Mary Beth Peil round out the exceptional cast of characters, with Jackie's antagonism Alicia providing some stellar moments. Great talent, great court cases, great season ending cliffhanger. I, for one, am eagerly looking forward to Season Four. For those of you who have NEVER watched this show before, BEGIN AT THE BEGINNING! The rest of us can revisit and savor the highlights of this fine program's latest season here.

The Good Wife is our favorite show on TV, intelligent & realistic.  A strong antidote to the naive belief that our adversarial criminal justice system is designed to produce justice aand that our electoral process is designed to pick the best people.  A great tutorial on the moral compromises people must make when trying to do good in such a system, and the ones they will make when they just care about coming out on top.

Update 1/11/13: I wrote this review for the first episode only, at the beginning of Season 3 when the DVD set for the season was not available. Amazon since cross-posted this review under the reviews for the whole season, so it appears as if I wrote two reviews for Season 3, which I actually did not. On to the review for Episode 1:

This show remains consistently high quality! Season 3 gets off to an exciting start with this initial episode titled, "A New Day."

Coming off of all the struggles of Season 2, Alicia Florrick (Julianna Margulies) has emerged as much more confident in herself both as a woman and as an attorney at Lockhart/Gardner.

In her personal life, Alicia has left her husband Peter Florrick (Chris Noth) after finding out he had a one-night stand years ago with Kalinda Sharma (Archie Panjaba), the firm's private investigator. In spite of the fact that Kalinda did not know Alicia then, this explosive revelation makes it impossible for Alicia to be anywhere near Kalinda without feeling an overwhelming urge to scream at her friend or burst into tears--which is a real problem since they have to work together on cases at Lockhart/Gardner.

Kalinda, who normally is a really tough nut, is shown at the end of Season 2 visibly heartbroken over losing her friendship with Alicia, which was one of the closest she'd ever had. On the heels of what Alicia sees as a double betrayal, she has kicked Peter out of their apartment and dumped him and his possessions into an apartment she got for him. As apparent retaliation, Peter, who just got re-elected to his old office as State's Attorney, strictly because of Alicia's high-profile loyalty and support during his campaign, at the end of Season 2 hires Cary Agos (Matt Czuchry) to be his second-in-command. Cary has been Alicia's enemy since Season 1 when she beat him out for an associate position at Lockhart/Gardner.

Alicia has begun talks with Lockhart/Gardner's barracuda divorce attorney, David Lee (the immensely talented Zach Grenier), and launched a torrid affair with Will Gardner (Josh Charles). For multiple reasons, Alicia and Will opt to keep their affair top secret: he is her boss, she is still legally married to Peter, and she doesn't want her kids to know about the affair.

On a professional front in this episode, Alicia takes the lead when the firm opts to defend a Muslim college student accused of assaulting a Jewish student during a campus brawl. Initially the case seems like a slam dunk for Alicia because no physical evidence exists to link their client to the crime, and Kalinda discovers a photo that offers an alibi for their client. Alicia is also convinced that the State's Attorney's office's hate-crime charge against her client is simply Peter showboating for the news media during his first week back in office. Then Cary and his prosecution team reveal their true plan--the same evidence that exonerates Alicia's client from the assault may implicate him as the primary suspect in a murder investigation.

This show does a great job every week (both for this first episode and all the other episodes of this season and the previous two seasons) of offering interesting cases for Lockhart/Gardner to represent. The writers keep these cases enthralling to viewers by offering spicy--and sometimes humorous--conflicts for the lawyers such as client chicanery to be worked around, in-house rivalries threatening to torpedo the success of a given case, or mysteries for the ruthlessly capable Kalinda to solve in order to prove a client's innocence or win a case. In addition, whatever the overarching legal plot, it always deftly intertwines with the many personal-relationship subplots occurring every week. Each of the characters is linked to multiple other characters in an ever spreading web of secrets, lies and conniving, but the show's highly talented writers (Michelle and Robert King) never drop any threads or cross the line into outright soapiness, which so much of nighttime drama seems to inevitably end up doing.

The story line, from season to season is riveting. Each actor adds to the drama in their own right. The writers for this series are so creative, and the actors are all so talented, I can't wait till Season 3 is available on DVD. I will be watching every episode from season 1 through 3.

"The Good Wife" is a masterful CBS legal and family drama. Season 3 continues its depiction of the travails and tribulations of a middle-age woman whose entire life was upended by the scandalous and criminal behavior of her husband, which had landed him in prison, and unable to care for his family. She is a law school graduate who has not practiced law for many years, after having given up her career to raise her children and manage the household. She re-entered the workforce as a junior associate at a prestigious law firm, and one of the name partners of her new firm is a former law school classmate, who had once been a very close friend. In this third season, the lead character has now become a premier litigator for her law firm, and regularly takes on the most challenging and high-profile cases. "The Good Wife" is an interesting and compelling television program, which is characterized by superb writing, intelligent and thought-provoking story lines, and excellent plot and character development. The acting is first-rate, with stellar performances by the ensemble cast, which includes Julianna Margulies, Chris Noth, Christine Baranski, Josh Charles, Matt Czuchry, Zach Grenier, Archie Panjabi, Alan Cumming, Michael J. Fox, Makenzie Vega, and Graham Phillips, to name a few. I thoroughly enjoyed watching "The Good Wife," and I found it to be decidedly engaging and entertaining. "The Good Wife" is an outstanding television series, which truly merits a five-star rating, along with an enthusiastic recommendation.
